timeline.message:
Add Normalize Pipeline Aggregation

This aggregation will perform normalizations of metrics
for a given series of data in the form of bucket values.

The aggregations supports the following normalizations

- rescale 0-1
- rescale 0-100
- percentage of sum
- mean normalization
- z-score normalization
- softmax normalization

To specify which normalization is to be used, it can be specified
in the normalize agg's `normalizer` field.

For example:

```
{
  "normalize": {
    "buckets_path": <>,
    "normalizer": "percent"
  }
}
```

Closes #51005.

timeline.bodyText: This'll want [role="xpack"] or so it'll get the little xpack bug.
timeline.author: nik9000
nik9000

replies.bodyText: so, I tried changing that parser to work here, but I think it deserves its own change. The InstantiatingObjectParser does not expose the Context in such a way that more constructor arguments can be passed in. I believe this can change, but I'd rather not do that here
replies.author: talevy

timeline.bodyText: The normalizer should probably be in hashCode and equals, right?
timeline.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: bucket.getAggregations().copyResults() does this without so much boiler plate.
timeline.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: unfortunately, that method does not work in this context. I think a more dedicated cleanup for this boilerplate can be tackled outside of this PR
replies.author: talevy

timeline.bodyText: Could this take a DoubleStream instead?
timeline.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: You'd only get a single pass but you wouldn't need to make Double objects which is kind of nice.
replies.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: Not that pipeline aggs are all that efficient here, but I feel compelled to save autoboxing when I can.
replies.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if we could have these normalizers all implement DoubleUnaryOperator instead of making an abstract class for them.
timeline.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: Do we need this bit? I don't remember needing it for top_metrics.
timeline.author: nik9000

timeline.bodyText: I still need to update docs to discuss all the different normalizers
timeline.author: talevy

timeline.bodyText: Should we make a note somewhere that this pipeline always uses a skip gap policy?
timeline.author: polyfractal
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+[role="xpack"]
+[testenv="basic"]
+[[search-aggregations-pipeline-normalize-aggregation]]
+=== Normalize Aggregation
+
+A parent pipeline aggregation which calculates the specific normalized/rescaled value for a specific bucket value.
+
+==== Syntax
+
+A `normalize` aggregation looks like this in isolation:
+
+[source,js]
+--------------------------------------------------
+{
+    "normalize": {
+        "buckets_path": "normalized",
+        "normalizer": "percent_of_sum"
+    }
+}
+--------------------------------------------------
+// NOTCONSOLE
+
+[[normalizer_pipeline-params]]

timeline.bodyText: Fine with normalizer, but wanted to also suggest method as a potential param name.  No strong opinion though :)
timeline.author: polyfractal

replies.bodyText: I was wishy washy on the naming here as well, and decided not to fret, but I too have leaned towards method earlier, so I am happy to do so here. especially given the overloading of the term across the stack.
replies.author: talevy

replies.bodyText: I've updated the naming to be method
replies.author: talevy

timeline.bodyText: Should we also check context.validateHasParent() to make sure this isn't at the top level?
timeline.author: polyfractal

replies.bodyText: ah, yes. I wasn't aware of this. thanks for bringing it up
replies.author: talevy

replies.bodyText: added a check and a test for this!
replies.author: talevy

timeline.bodyText:
Do we know if this works with a terms agg as the parent?  It feels like it should (e.g. it doesn't require any specific ordering of the buckets, unlike something like a moving avg which needs an ordering).
If we think it should work with terms we should tweak this to not use a HistogramFactory directly.  BucketScriptPipelineAggregator has an example of how to generically build buckets from any InternalMultiBucketAggregation (the internal agg can create buckets too, not just the factory).
timeline.author: polyfractal

replies.author: talevy

replies.bodyText: Yikes! I'm sorry I didn't notice this one!
replies.author: nik9000

replies.bodyText: thanks, I've updated to include a test for terms and use a more generic way to make new buckets
replies.author: talevy
